awd_abstract_narration:
The Polymath Jr is an online program that provides hundreds of college students the opportunity to participate in mathematical research. This highly inclusive program allows each participant to choose how much they want to get out of the program by selecting how much time they want to dedicate. The program presents a variety of research projects in many branches of mathematics. Each project is mentored by a professor and graduate students. The program supports students who might otherwise have no opportunity to explore their mathematical potential. The participants learn how mathematical research is conducted, and many participants also publish papers in research journals. The program helps participants explore various other engagement opportunities in mathematical research.

The 2023 Polymath Jr program will include research projects in number theory, combinatorics, topology, algebra, probability, complex analysis, machine learning, math education, and more. We focus on problems that consist of separate parts at different levels of difficulty. The staggered projects allow supporting groups of students with varied mathematical backgrounds. The program also includes a component for training graduate students to mentor undergraduate research projects and run research groups.

Program website is at https://geometrynyc.wixsite.com/polymathreu

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Polymath Jr program is to provide research opportunities to undergraduate students. It supports a large number of students, most of which have no other opportunities. During the summer of 2023, the program supported approximately 300 students. These students were divided among 14 research projects in a wide variety of mathematical subfields, according to their preferences. Each project was run 1-3 professors who are experts in the field, with graduate students and postdocs as additional mentors, and consisted of about 22 students. The entire work was done online, relying on Zoom, a dedicated Wiki server, Discord, Overleaf, and more.

The research projects resulted in many papers and manuscripts. According to the end-of-program survey, the participants were very happy about their experience in the program. More importantly, many students who had no opportunities in the past used the program to demonstrate their mathematical abilities and potential. Others learned what mathematical research looks like and accomplished other goals. Beyond the research work, participants were also trained in giving talks, writing mathematical proofs, using mathematical software, applying to graduate school, and more.

Providing advanced mathematical opportunities to hundreds of students has multiple positive outcomes. Students who did not have opportunities before and demonstrated their enthusiasm and potential rely on the program to continue to graduate school and to other advanced opportunities. Other participants spent less time on the program and relied on it to get a first impression of mathematical research and whether they wish to pursue it in the future. Most participants are in between these two cases.

Beyond supporting more students on their way to graduate school and math-related careers, the program also increases STEM-literacy in general. Participants will continue to careers in most parts of society, and spread their enthusiasm about mathematics. For example, having more schoolteachers who understand mathematical research could have a significant impact.

The Polymath Jr program also trained graduate students in mentoring undergraduate research. These graduate students participated in a pre-program workshop, attended regular group meetings, and had personal mentors for undergraduate mentoring. They received hands-on experience by working as mentors in Polymath Jr projects. We encourage these graduate students to pursue more undergraduate mentoring in the future and help them obtain such jobs. Thus, the program has a long-lasting effect on undergraduate mentoring.

People who participated in the program are enthusiastic about supporting the younger generation. Past Polymath Jr participants who continued to graduate school are now acting as graduate mentors in the program. Graduate mentors who completed graduate school now run their own research projects at the Polymath Jr. Many undergraduate participants joined the program for a second summer.
